get.summary: Use this method to retrieve all the AppConfigs.

parameters.description:
A collection of response resources can be filtered by a logical expression string that includes JSON tag references to values in each resource, literal values, and logical operators. If a resource does not have the specified tag, its value is assumed to be null.

Literal values include numbers (integer and floating-point), and quoted (both single- or double-quoted) literal strings, and 'null'. The following operators are commonly used in filter expressions:

|  Op   |  Description               | 
|  --   |  -----------               | 
|  ==   |  Equal                     | 
|  !=   |  Not Equal                 | 
|  >    |  Greater Than              | 
|   >=  |  Greater Than or Equal To  | 
|  <    |  Less Than                 | 
|  <=   |  Less Than or Equal To     | 
|  and  |  Logical AND               | 
|  ~    |  Matches Regex             | 
|  !~   |  Does Not Match Regex      | 
|  or   |  Logical OR                | 
|  not  |  Logical NOT               | 
|  ()   |  Groupping Operators       |
parameters.name: _filter

parameters.description:
A collection of response resources can be sorted by their JSON tags. For a 'flat' resource, the tag name is straightforward. If sorting is allowed on non-flat hierarchical resources, the service should implement a qualified naming scheme such as dot-qualification to reference data down the hierarchy. If a resource does not have the specified tag, its value is assumed to be null.)

Specify this parameter as a comma-separated list of JSON tag names. The sort direction can be specified by a suffix separated by whitespace before the tag name. The suffix 'asc' sorts the data in ascending order. The suffix 'desc' sorts the data in descending order. If no suffix is specified the data is sorted in ascending order.
parameters.name: _order_by

parameters.description:
A collection of response resources can be transformed by specifying a set of JSON tags to be returned. For a “flat” resource, the tag name is straightforward. If field selection is allowed on non-flat hierarchical resources, the service should implement a qualified naming scheme such as dot-qualification to reference data down the hierarchy. If a resource does not have the specified tag, the tag does not appear in the output resource.

Specify this parameter as a comma-separated list of JSON tag names.
parameters.name: _fields

parameters.description: The integer index (zero-origin) of the offset into a collection of resources. If omitted or null the value is assumed to be '0'.
parameters.name: _offset

parameters.description: The integer number of resources to be returned in the response. The service may impose maximum value. If omitted the service may impose a default value.
parameters.name: _limit

parameters.description: The service-defined string used to identify a page of resources. A null value indicates the first page.
parameters.name: _page_token

parameters.description:
A collection of response resources can be filtered by a logical expression string that includes JSON tag references to values in each resource, literal values, and logical operators. If a resource does not have the specified tag, its value is assumed to be null.

Literal values include numbers (integer and floating-point), and quoted (both single- or double-quoted) literal strings, and 'null'. The following operators are commonly used in filter expressions:

|  Op   |  Description               | 
|  --   |  -----------               | 
|  ==   |  Equal                     | 
|  !=   |  Not Equal                 | 
|  >    |  Greater Than              | 
|   >=  |  Greater Than or Equal To  | 
|  <    |  Less Than                 | 
|  <=   |  Less Than or Equal To     | 
|  and  |  Logical AND               | 
|  ~    |  Matches Regex             | 
|  !~   |  Does Not Match Regex      | 
|  or   |  Logical OR                | 
|  not  |  Logical NOT               | 
|  ()   |  Groupping Operators       |
parameters.name: _filter

parameters.description:
A collection of response resources can be sorted by their JSON tags. For a 'flat' resource, the tag name is straightforward. If sorting is allowed on non-flat hierarchical resources, the service should implement a qualified naming scheme such as dot-qualification to reference data down the hierarchy. If a resource does not have the specified tag, its value is assumed to be null.)

Specify this parameter as a comma-separated list of JSON tag names. The sort direction can be specified by a suffix separated by whitespace before the tag name. The suffix 'asc' sorts the data in ascending order. The suffix 'desc' sorts the data in descending order. If no suffix is specified the data is sorted in ascending order.
parameters.name: _order_by

parameters.description:
A collection of response resources can be transformed by specifying a set of JSON tags to be returned. For a “flat” resource, the tag name is straightforward. If field selection is allowed on non-flat hierarchical resources, the service should implement a qualified naming scheme such as dot-qualification to reference data down the hierarchy. If a resource does not have the specified tag, the tag does not appear in the output resource.

Specify this parameter as a comma-separated list of JSON tag names.
parameters.name: _fields

parameters.description: The integer index (zero-origin) of the offset into a collection of resources. If omitted or null the value is assumed to be '0'.
parameters.name: _offset

parameters.description: The integer number of resources to be returned in the response. The service may impose maximum value. If omitted the service may impose a default value.
parameters.name: _limit

parameters.description: The service-defined string used to identify a page of resources. A null value indicates the first page.
parameters.name: _page_token

apiPageInfo.description:
PageInfo represents both server-driven and client-driven pagination response.
Server-driven pagination is a model in which the server returns some
amount of data along with an token indicating there is more data
and where subsequent queries can get the next page of data.
Client-driven pagination is a model in which rows are addressable by
offset and page size (limit).

offset.description:
The service may optionally include the offset of the next page of resources.
A null value indicates no more pages.

page_token.description:
The service response should contain a string to indicate
the next page of resources.
A null value indicates no more pages.

size.description: The service may optionally include the total number of resources being paged.

repo.title: The repo e.g. GitHub for the Appliation

ticket_link.title: The ticket link e.g. Jira link

commit.title: The commit Id of the Artifact in repo

repo.title: The repo which stores the Artifact

artifact.title: Artifact for resolved manifest used for the ApplicationInstance

kube_cluster.title: Kubernetes Cluster on which the ApplicationInstance is deployed

key.title: The key value of secret (note: value is stored on kubernetes secret

path.title: The path on vault for the Secrets (e.g. /qa0-secrets)

type.title: The type of secret (e.g. opaque, or tls)

secrets.title: The list of Secrets stored against the path on vault
